clinical_study.brief_title: Developing a Non-contact Sleep Apnoea Detector, Suitable for Home Studies- The Safescan Study
clinical_study.official_title: Developing a Non-contact Sleep Apnoea Detector, Suitable for Home Studies- The Safescan Study.

collaborator.agency: Iceni Labs Ltd, Warwickshire, United Kingdom

brief_summary.textblock: Sleep apnoea (SA) is a common condition in adults and children that causes disturbed sleep and daytime symptoms. It is characterised by disrupted breathing with disturbed sleep patterns. In adults this can lead to dangerous daytime sleepiness affecting for example driving performance. In children it may lead to hyperactivity in the day and poor school performance. There are a number of techniques for diagnosing the disorder but they can affect the quality of sleep which sometimes makes them inaccurate. Most are unsuitable for small children who cannot understand the value of the tests and tend to remove the monitoring wires and devices in the night. This study aims to validate a new non contact device "Safescan", based on low power radar technology, which can be put under a bed and record breathing patterns with no measuring device in contact with the sleeper. In this initial study the device will be validated in adults, against the gold standard of polysomnography (PSG) in the sleep laboratory at Royal Papworth Hospital.

primary_outcome.measure: Agreement between the Apnoea hypopnea index (AHI) per hour as measured overnight by the Safescan device and by clinical polysomnography
primary_outcome.description: Agreement in AHI +/- 10% between Safescan device and PSG. A comparison will be made between the 2 AHI's for each participant. The proportion in whom there is an agreement within +/- 10% will be reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Agreement between the Safescan device respiratory rate (RR) as breaths per minute overnight and RR from PSG
secondary_outcome.description: Agreement +/- 1 breath per minute between Safescan device and PSG

secondary_outcome.measure: Agreement in recorded body position between Safescan device and PSG
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of 1 minute epochs during the the Safescan body position is in agreement with that of the PSG

arm_group.description: Data from this cohort will be used to develop the software algorithms
Data from this cohort will be used to validate the software algorithms

study_pop.textblock: Patients referred to the sleep laboratory for inpatient polysomnography, irrespective of working or known diagnosis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Aged 18 years or older
- Able to give informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient with known sleep disordered breathing using a treatment device (e.g. continuous positive airway pressure) on the night of the study.
- Polysomnography study records less than 4 hours of respiratory data
